Capítulo 3, concluindo que, a areia após fluidizada, aproxima-se das suas condições no estado 

crítico, apresentando uma mesma densidade relativa final (Dr ? 30%). 

Durante a instalação das estacas por fluidização pressupõe-se que não ocorra nenhum 

embuchamento (plug) das mesmas, visto que no interior da estaca há um fluxo água sobre 

pressão se opondo a entra de material (areia). Assim, assumiu-se que a resistência ao 

arrancamento axial desenvolveu-se ao longo do fuste dos modelos (área superficial externa da 

estaca). 

A partir dos resultados dos ensaios de arrancamento, calcularam-se os coeficientes de 

empuxo lateral de serviço (Ks), da mesma forma realizada para testes em solo não fluidizado. 

A tensão efetiva no solo (?'vo) foi calculada no ponto médio da profundidade instalada, 

utilizando o peso específico submerso estimado para a areia fluidizada (Dr = 30%). O ângulo 

de atrito entre o solo e a parede da estaca (?) foi considerado igual a 0,78?'cv (? = 20,75º), de 

acordo com o apresentado no Capítulo 4. 

Para maiores tensões de confinamento (L ? 800 mm), os valores de Ks mostraram-se 

relativamente constantes, correspondendo a aproximadamente 0,10 (testes realizados 

imediatamente e 4 horas) e 0,15 (testes realizados 24 e 48 horas), conforme apresentado na 

Figura 5.30a,b.

Os valores encontrados para Ks estão muito abaixo do esperado, considerando valores 

mínimos da ordem de 0,20 a 0,40 para estacas cravadas em areia fofa, mesmo após sofrer 

considerada fadiga na resistência de atrito lateral, causada por um grande número de ciclos de 

carregamento devido à cravação (Salgado, 2008 e Basu et al., 2011). Assim, esses resultados

140 

sugerem que as tensões no entorno do fuste das estacas apresentam valores baixos durante o 

arrancamento das mesmas, deste modo é provável (i) que estas estacas em condições 1G e sob 

baixos níveis de confinamento respondam de maneira intermediária entre estacas cravadas 

(displacement piles) e escavadas (non-displacement piles); como também (ii) que a estrutura 

do solo torne-se frágil e colapsível após o processo de fluidização. Porém, em condições reais 

(estacas instaladas em campo) estima-se que este comportamento peculiar encontrado nos 

ensaios de laboratório seja minimizado pelas maiores tensões de confinamento.  

Os resultados de coeficientes de determinação para os valores de coeficientes de 

empuxo lateral de serviço (Ks) expostos na Figura 5.30a,b, com valores de ajuste de 25% a 

61%, justificam-se pois os mesmos foram calculados para cada grupo de ensaios 

individualmente, sendo que estes ajustes se elevam caso considerado todos os ensaios em 

apenas dois grupos, para valores de 42% (0h e 4h) e 75% (24h e 24h), conforme apresentado 

na Figura 5.31b. 

Comparando os resultados de ensaios de arrancamento no centro do tanque de 

modelos de estaca instalados por fluidização (i) por peso próprio e (ii) de forma suspensa, 

verificou-se valores próximos e comportamento semelhante (Figura 5.31a,b), 

independentemente do fato do leito fluidizado exibir geometria distinta, conforme apresentado 

no item 5.2.1 deste capítulo. Esta constatação é corroborada pelo fato de que a banda de 

cisalhamento (ts) desenvolve-se localizada junto ao fuste de estaca, independentemente do 

diâmetro da estaca, sendo sua espessura constante e dependente da densidade relativa, das 

tensões de confinamento e da rugosidade superficial da estaca. Conforme abordado no 

Capítulo 4, a banda de cisalhamento (ts) foi estimada em torno de 2,5d50, sendo igual a       

0,52 mm nestes experimentos. Como a densidade relativa final (Dr ? 30%), as tensões de 

confinamento, a rugosidade superficial da estaca e o diâmetro do grão mantiveram-se 

inalterados nos dois tipos de ensaios (peso próprio e suspenso), a banda de cisalhamento (ts) 

foi a mesma. Os resultados de capacidade de carga obtidos por Stracke (2012) referem-se à  

11 ensaios de modelos instalados na forma suspensa, fazendo uso de hastes diâmetros 

externos de 6,1 a 16,2 mm, realizados 24 horas após a instalação. Os valores do coeficiente de 

empuxo lateral de serviço foram calculados com os mesmos parâmetros adotados nesta 

pesquisa.

Figura 5.31 – (a) e (b) Comparação dos resultados de arrancamento em solo fluidizado com Stracke (2012). 

 

Analisando o tempo entre a instalação e o arrancamento dos modelos desta pesquisa, 

concluiu-se que os resultados dos ensaios de arrancamento em solo fluidizado 24 e 48 horas 

após a instalação dos modelos foram similares entre si, sendo ambos em torno de 47% 

superiores aos valores de Qf e Ks obtidos nos ensaios realizados imediatamente e 4 horas após 

a instalação, sendo que estes também resultaram em valores próximos. Assim, concluiu-se 

que o solo fluidizado apresenta ganho de capacidade de carga no tempo (setup). Estima-se que 

o aumento das poropressões causado pela fluidização demanda mais tempo para dissipar-se 

em comparação a estacas instaladas em areia não fluidizada. Além disso, ao final do processo 

de instalação dos modelos por fluidização, observou-se o fechamento da cavidade com a 

deposição dos grãos em suspensão, conforme relatado no Capítulo 3 e no item 5.2.1. Assim, a 

redistribuição e reacomodação dos grãos e a dissipação das poropressões geradas apresentam-

se como mecanismos, em potencial, responsáveis pelos efeitos de setup observados. 

Princípios de análise dimensional através de termos ? (Teorema de Buckingham) 

foram aplicados nos resultados de arrancamento em solo fluidizado desta pesquisa, da mesma 

forma realizada para os resultados em solo não fluidizado. Este artifício propicia a melhor 

observação do setup, pois os resultados apresentam-se independentes dos diâmetros externos 

dos modelos de estaca (Figura 5.32a,b).

5.2.7 Comparação dos resultados de arrancamento em solo fluidizado e não fluidizado 

Constatou-se que a resistência ao arrancamento dos modelos cravadas em solo não 

fluidizado (Figura 5.33a) foi superior à resistência ao arrancamento dos modelos instalados 

em solo fluidizado (Figura 5.33b), assim como observado por Stracke (2012). O modo de 

instalação (com e sem fluidização) e as condições iniciais da areia (densidade relativa) antes 

do carregamento axial de tração são algumas das variáveis que afetam a capacidade de carga 

lateral última de estacas em areia, conforme relatado no capítulo 2.

Capítulo 5 – Apresentação e Análise dos Resultados 

 

Instalação e Capacidade de Carga Axial de Estacas Modelo Fluidizadas em Solos Arenosos 

Após fluidizado, o solo apresenta densidade relativa em torno de 30%, próximo ao seu 

estado crítico, independentemente da densidade relativa de compactação a qual a amostra foi 

preparada, sendo de 50% e 90%. Tal constatação é relevante para o fenômeno de fluidização 

modelado sob condições de instalação por fluidização em campo, como é almejado, pois esta 

ocorrência não é afetada por efeito de escala, apesar da substancial diferença entre as tensões 

de confinamento, as quais existem entre os testes no laboratório e os testes em campo.  

A zona perturbada pela fluidização durante a instalação das estacas diminui a 

densidade relativa no entorno do eixo do fuste das mesmas, reduzindo a capacidade de carga 

axial à tração. Os resultados de Qf ao arrancamento axial mostraram ser dependentes do 

comprimento instalado da estaca modelo (L) e da densidade relativa da areia (Dr) no entorno 

da mesma. Quanto maior a densidade relativa do solo (Dr), o comprimento cravado (L) e o 

diâmetro (de) da estaca, maior é a carga última de resistência lateral (Qf) observada.  

Os coeficients de empuxo lateral de serviço (Ks) foram calculados a partir das cargas 

de ruptura ao arrancamento axial (Qf) e mostraram-se maiores quanto maior da densidade 

relativa (Dr) e menores as tensões de confinamento (?'vo).  

Os valores de Ks obtidos em solo não fluidizado, para as maiores tensões de 

confinamento (L = 500 mm), mostraram-se relativamente constantes, correspondendo a 

aproximadamente 0,40 para Dr = 50% e 0,60 para Dr = 90%. Já em solo fluidizado               

(Dr ? 30%), os valores de Ks obtidos foram de aproximadamente 0,10 (0h e 4h) e 0,15         

(24h e 48h), sendo relativamente constantes para as maiores tensões de confinamento            

(L ? 800 mm). 

Não foi observado ganho de resistência no tempo para as estacas ensaiadas à tração 

axial em solo não fluidizado, para testes realizados imediatamente (0h) e 24h após a cravação. 

Em contra partida, as estacas ensaiadas à tração axial em solo fluidizado apresentaram ganho 

de capacidade de carga com tempo de 24 horas após a instalação (efeito de setup). O processo 

de ganho de resistência foi relacionado com a dissipação das poropressões geradas pelo 

jateamento e o rearranjo/reacomodação dos grãos na cavidade perturbada/erodida no entorno 

do fuste da estaca após o término da fluidização.  

A Figura 5.34a,b apresenta todos os resultados dos ensaios de arrancamento desta 

pesquisa, em solo fluidizado e não fluidizado, de forma adimensionalizada através dos 

coeficientes de profundidade, de capacidade de carga e de empuxo lateral de serviço. 

Comparando os resultados de capacidade de carga adimensionalizados (i) para testes 

realizados imediatamente (0h) após a instalação dos modelos (situação mais desfavorável), 

verificou-se uma redução nos valores de Qf em torno de 66% e 77%, para as densidades

144 

relativas iniciais de 50% e 90% (não fluidizadas), respectivamente, devido à fluidização do 

solo; (ii) para testes realizados 24h após a instalação dos modelos (situação mais favorável), 

verificou-se uma redução média nos valores de Qf de 52% e 68%, causada pela fluidização do 

solo e posterior ganho de resistência (efeito de setup), para as densidades relativas iniciais de 

50% e 90% (não fluidizada), respectivamente.

próximos aos estimados por Mezzomo (2009), conforme relatado no Capítulo 3, estando em 

conformidade com o adotado (Dr = 30%).  

As curvas carga versus deslocamento típicas obtidas nos ensaios de arrancamento  

axial em solo fluidizado (Dr ? 30%) e não fluidizado (Dr = 50% e 90%) são apresentadas na 

Figura 5.35, para modelos de diâmetro externo de 16,2 mm e profundidade instalada de       

360 mm. Estes ensaios foram realizados 24 horas após a instalação dos modelos. Tais curvas 

apresentam deslocamentos muito pequenos até atingirem a ruptura, a qual ocorreu e forma 

frágil. Os ensaios foram realizados através de controle de carga, conforme relatado no  

Capítulo 4. Além disso, os deslocamentos necessários, para ocorrer a ruptura da estaca por 

atrito lateral, são menores em ensaios de tração em comparação com ensaios de compressão.  

 

 

Figura 5.35 – Curvas carga versus deslocamento das estacas modelo para solo fluidizado e não fluidizado. 

  

A Figura 5.36a, referente ao ensaio de arrancamento axial realizado no modelo de 

diâmetro externo igual a 21,3 mm e profundidade cravada de 360 mm em solo não fluidizado 

(Dr = 50%), apresenta através da curva carga versus deslocamento a ruptura frágil que ocorre 

na interface solo/estaca, para carga de arrancamento (Qf) correspondente a um deslocamento 

de 10% do diâmetro externo do modelo (de). Já a Figura 5.36b apresenta um detalhe da curva 

carga versus deslocamento, com destaque para início da ocorrência dos deslocamentos na 

ruptura. Este ensaio foi realizado imediatamente (0h) após a cravação do modelo. 

 



 
Capítulo 5 – Apresentação e Análise dos Resultados 
 

 

Larissa de Brum Passini – Tese de Doutorado – PPGEC/UFRGS, 2015 

 

146 

   

Figura 5.36 – (a) e (b) Detalhes da ruptura ao arrancamento a partir da curva carga versus deslocamento da 

estaca modelo para solo não fluidizado. 

 

Curvas similares a estas foram apresentadas por Alawneh et al. (1999) e Shanker et al. 

(2007) em seus experimentos de laboratório para ensaios de arrancamento de modelos de 

estacas, ambos em areia seca. 

Assim como nos resultados dos ensaios de instalação por fluidização, os resultados 

dos ensaios de arrancamento não apresentaram influência dos efeitos de fronteira (D/de) 

devido à proximidade entre as escalas trabalhadas, como também os efeitos de escala 

relacionados aos diferentes diâmetros de estacas não foram observados (de/d50). Mais uma 

vez, como os ensaios foram realizados em modelo reduzido a 1G, os resultados de capacidade 

de carga (Qf) e coeficiente de empuxo lateral de serviço (Ks) devem ser considerados 

introdutórios a estudos realizados em maiores escalas (ts/de <0,0012 até 0,0100 e               

de/d50 > 1000 até 8000) e tensões de confinamento, antes do emprego destes parâmetros em 

projetos de engenharia offshore. Entretanto, os ensaios desta pesquisa forneceram resultados 

sólidos, possibilitando uma adequada orientação da influência da fluidização sobre a 

capacidade de carga de estacas, dentro do intervalo de escalas trabalhadas.  

5.3 Resultados dos ensaios em solo argiloso 

5.3.1 Profundidades cravadas sem jateamento  

Os resultados de 48 ensaios de profundidade cravada por peso próprio sem o 

jateamento do solo argiloso, utilizando hastes de 14,0 e 16,2 mm, são apresentados na        

Figura 5.37. As hastes foram liberadas para cravação por peso próprio, posicionadas na 

superfície do solo, sendo os testes realizados no centro do tanque. As massas ao ar das hastes 

(a) (b)

determinaram as profundidades de cravação, conforme relatado no Capítulo 2. Para o cálculo 

da resistência não-drenada (Su) foram utilizados os dados de cravação das hastes em solo 

argiloso por peso próprio, através da equação básica derivada da teoria de equilíbrio limite 

(equação 2.10), segundo a norma API-RP-2A (2005), previamente apresentada no Capítulo 2. 

O peso de cada haste foi considerado como capacidade de carga última (Qd). A área de ponta 

(Ap) foi considerada plena e a área lateral (As) foi considerada a externa a haste. O valor do 

fator adimensional de adesão solo/estaca (?) foi adotado como 1,0, conforme discutido nos 

Capítulos 2 e 3, e o fator adimensional de capacidade de carga (Nc) foi adotado como 9, de 

acordo com a norma API-RP-2A (2005). Os valores calculados de Su para cada ensaio de 

cravação por retro análise resultaram em um valor médio igual 0,45 kPa. A Figura 5.38 

apresenta os resultados de cravação medidos versus previstos, fazendo uso do Su = 0,45 kPa.

Foram realizados ensaios de mini palheta (mini vane) 24 horas após a preparação da 

mistura argilosa, onde foi obtido o valor médio de Su = 0,50 kPa (Figura 5.39). O 

equipamento utilizado foi desenvolvido por Gauer (2010). O ensaio de palheta, conhecido 

internacionalmente como Vane Test, é um dos métodos mais utilizados na determinação em 

campo da resistência ao cisalhamento não-drenada (Su) de depósitos de argilas moles, devido 

à sua simplicidade, rapidez de execução e relativo baixo custo, segundo Schnaid (2009).  

 

 

Figura 5.39 – Resistência não-drenada (Su) através de ensaio de mini palheta. 

 

O valor médio da resistência não-drenada (Su) obtido por retro análise foi próximo ao 

medido nos ensaios de mini palheta. Assim, conclui-se que os resultados dos ensaios de 

cravação por peso próprio foram adequados para estimar a resistência não-drenada (Su) do 

solo argiloso utilizado nos ensaios de laboratório. Para tornar os resultados de comportamento 

independente da escala, uma curva de comportamento adimensional de cravação por peso 

próprio em solo argiloso é apresentada na Figura 5.40. O eixo das abscissas apresenta a razão 

entre a resistência não-drenada média (Su) e a tensão efetiva vertical (?'vo) associada a cada 

cravação, e o eixo das ordenadas apresenta a razão entre a profundidade cravada (L) e o 

diâmetro externo (de) de cada haste.  

 



149

Figura 5.40 – Su/?'vo versus L/de para cravação por peso próprio em leito argiloso. 

 

Através da Figura 5.40, pôde-se observar que os valores de Su/?'vo convergiram para 

um valor igual a 0,60, ao contrário do valor esperado de 0,25 para um solo normalmente 

adensado, devido a distorções causadas pelo desconfinamento do solo (camada superior), 

baixos níveis de tensões e efeito de escala, por ser um ensaio em modelo reduzido, não 

atendendo à similaridade completa com relação aos ensaios de campo. A relação Su/?'vo é 

semelhante a apresenta por Jung (2012) para um dos seus materiais argilosos, conforme 

relatado no Capítulo 3.   

5.3.2 Profundidades cravadas com jateamento  

Os resultados de 8 ensaios de instalação em solo argiloso aplicando o jateamento

permitindo o registro da medida dos deslocamentos no tempo. As massas ao ar dos modelos 

de estaca ensaiados foram de 150 e 275 g (de = 14,0 mm), e 220 e 400 g (de = 16,2 mm). Os 

modelos foram posicionados na superfície do solo e então liberados para cravação por peso 

próprio no centro do tanque, com a aplicação do jateamento de água.

Figura 5.41 – Resultados de cravação dos modelos de estaca com jateamento (a) de = 14,0 mm e                           

(b) de = 16,2 mm em leito argiloso. 

 

Conforme relatado no Capítulo 4, os jatos verticais circulares causaram rupturas 

hidráulicas no leito argiloso e não removeram massa de solo por erosão. A mistura argilosa 

aderiu-se ao fuste dos modelos, impossibilitando que a água ejetada na ponta da estaca 

atingisse a superfície. A formação de uma cavidade erodida nesta região, conforme descrita 

no Capítulo 3, através de ensaios com o uso de hastes suspensas, não ocorreu. A água 

provinda do processo de jateamento percolou pelas rupturas, atingindo as paredes do tanque, e 

posteriormente subindo à superfície, sendo extravasada para fora do mesmo, mantendo a 

lâmina d’água constante nos ensaios. Com a ocorrência das rupturas hidráulicas                     

(Figura 5.42a,b), os modelos penetraram no solo argiloso além da profundidade atingida sob 

ação de suas massas (peso próprio). Cada degrau observado nas Figuras 5.42a,b corresponde a 

ocorrência de uma ruptura hidráulica.

5.3.3 Conclusões relacionadas aos ensaios em leito argiloso 

A metodologia de instalação proposta, através da aplicação de jatos de água, verticais 

circulares únicos e contínuos, não foi adequada, dentro da faixa de vazões (Q0) e de 

velocidades (U0) de saída do jato aplicada. As profundidades de cravação por peso próprio 

com e sem a utilização de jatos foram próximas, sendo assim, apenas a massa dos modelos 

governou o processo de cravação. Os jatos verticais circulares únicos e contínuos causaram 

rupturas hidráulicas no leito argiloso e não removeram massa de solo por erosão. O material 

argiloso aderiu-se no fuste dos modelos, não permitindo a percolação da água e o arraste de 

massa de solo por esta interface. Assim, sugere-se para pesquisas futuras em leito argiloso,         

(i) a aplicação de jatos em diferentes direções, partindo da ponteira e do fuste da estaca,          

(ii) o aumento da faixa de velocidades (U0) de saída do jato utilizadas, uma vez que a 

velocidades dos jatos regem o processo em argilas, conforme relatado no Capítulo 3, além do 

(iii) o controle da velocidade de instalação, constituindo-se uma metodologia intermediária 

entre o uso de tubos suspensas (Jung 2012) e por peso próprio (presente pesquisa). 

5.4 Considerações finais 

A partir da apresentação e análise dos resultados dos ensaios de laboratório em modelo 

reduzido em solo arenoso fino, realizados nesta pesquisa de doutorado, é possível prosseguir 

para as conclusões deste trabalho, o qual teve como objetivo o estudo da geometria e da 

instalação por peso próprio de modelos com uso de jatos verticais circulares, e da capacidade 

de carga axial à tração de estacas instaladas em solos fluidizado e não fluidizado. 



 
Capítulo 6 – Conclusões 
 

 

Larissa de Brum Passini – Tese de Doutorado – PPGEC/UFRGS, 2015 

 

152 

Capítulo 6 – CONCLUSÕES 

6.1   Considerações iniciais 

Este capítulo apresenta as conclusões desta tese de doutorado, baseadas no programa 

experimental fundamentado em estudos relatados na literatura sobre fundações profundas e 

jateamento de solos, e na análise dos resultados dos ensaios laboratório em modelo reduzido 

(1G), de geometria, instalação e arrancamento axial, de estacas torpedo, sem aletas, em solo 

arenoso fino fluidizado e não fluidizado. Inicia-se pela conclusão geral, seguindo para as 

conclusões específicas relacionadas aos ensaios realizados em leito arenoso. Por fim, são 

apresentadas sugestões para pesquisas futuras. 

6.2 Conclusão geral  

O programa experimental executado atingiu os objetivos propostos na pesquisa, o qual 

almejou o estudo dos mecanismos e do comportamento de modelos instalados através da 

fluidização do solo, e suas respectivas capacidades de carga axial à tração. As grandezas das 

escalas de comprimento adotadas para os ensaios, em modelo reduzido, foram adequadas, 

propiciando um trabalho de laboratório satisfatório.  

6.3 Conclusões específicas  

A metodologia de instalação proposta, através do emprego de jatos de água verticais 

circulares, quando aplicados desde a superfície do leito, foi adequada, possibilitando a 

cravação da estaca no solo, segundo mecanismos identificados e controlados. Tais 

mecanismos, constatados a partir de ensaios com haste suspensa, foram úteis ao entendimento 

dos processos de instalação de estacas torpedo por fluidização do solo.  

As profundidades de instalação atingidas por fluidização do leito arenoso fino          

(L/de > 50) foram superiores às profundidades cravadas pela ação do peso próprio sem 

fluidização (L/de <5), indicando a vantagem do uso de jateamento de água em solos arenosos. 

As profundidades de instalação atingidas no modelo, por fluidização do solo arenoso fino, são 

próximas aos resultados de profundidade crítica (T3) encontrados por Niven (1998) e Stracke 

(2012), em seus ensaios de fluidização de leito arenoso fino com o uso de haste suspensa.  



153 
Capítulo 6 – Conclusões 

 

Instalação e Capacidade de Carga Axial de Estacas Modelo Fluidizadas em Solos Arenosos 

A geometria da zona fluidizada durante a instalação dos modelos de estaca 

permaneceu constante e paralela ao fuste (dH ? 2de), independentemente da vazão aplicada e 

da densidade relativa inicial do solo. Ao final da instalação dos modelos, a geometria da zona 

fluidizada se amplia gradativamente (dH ? 6de), sendo maior quanto maior a vazão aplicada, 

assumindo o mesmo comportamento da fluidização por tubos suspensos. 

A velocidade de saída do jato (U0), o diâmetro interno (di), o qual é o mesmo diâmetro 

do jato (dj), e consequentemente a vazão (Q0), são parâmetros importantes no processo de 

penetração por fluidização do solo arenoso, e estão todos diretamente relacionados. A vazão 

(Q0) controla o processo de fluidização em areias, conforme as constatações da literatura 

apresentadas no Capítulo 3. 

Quando maior a massa (m) do modelo, maior a profundidade de instalação (L) atingida 

para uma mesma vazão (Q0) aplicada e, quanto maior a vazão (Q0) imposta, para uma mesma 

massa (m) de modelo, maior a profundidade de instalação (L) atingida. Ambas as situações 

considerando o solo arenoso compactado em uma mesma densidade relativa (Dr).  

O aumento da densidade relativa (Dr) diminui a profundidade instalada (L), para um 

modelo de mesma massa (m) de estaca e vazão (Q0) de jateamento.  

As curvas de instalação no tempo, através da fluidização do leito arenoso, mostraram 

que a velocidade de penetração é inicialmente alta, associada à atuação do peso próprio. Em 

seguida, a velocidade de cravação decresce de forma gradual até o momento em que modelo 

para de cravar. Para ensaios dentro da mesma escala, considerando uma mesma vazão (Q0) e 

densidade relativa do solo: quanto maior a massa (m), maior a velocidade inicial de instalação 

(v), maior é a profundidade atingida e menor o tempo (t) para penetrar uma mesma 

profundidade.  

Seguindo as leis de análise dimensional, uma expressão para a penetração dos modelos 

de estaca foi apresentada, a qual leva em consideração as características físicas da estaca 

(massa e diâmetro), as características físicas da areia (densidade relativa inicial e diâmetro do 

grão), o caudal de fluidização e as características do fluido (coeficiente de viscosidade 

cinemática da água). 

A análise da capacidade de carga axial à tração, dos modelos instalados em solo 

fluidizado e não fluidizado, evidenciou a influência das condições de compactação do solo 

(densidade relativa da areia) e do modo de instalação das estacas, tais como cravação 

monotônica e por fluidização. A capacidade de carga axial à tração dos modelos mostrou-se 

independente da vazão imposta durante a instalação dos modelos por fluidização.  



 
Capítulo 6 – Conclusões 
 

 

Larissa de Brum Passini – Tese de Doutorado – PPGEC/UFRGS, 2015 

 

154 

Constatou-se que a resistência ao arrancamento axial dos modelos cravados em solo 

não fluidizado foi superior a resistência ao arrancamento dos modelos instalados em solo 

fluidizado. Após a fluidização, a areia apresentou mesma densidade relativa final, próxima do 

seu estado crítico (Dr ? 30%), independente da densidade relativa inicial (Dr = 50 e 90%) de 

compactação. 

 A resistência lateral última axial à tração (Qf) das estacas mostrou-se maior quanto 

maior a densidade relativa do solo (Dr), o comprimento cravado (L) e o diâmetro (de) da 

estaca. O coeficiente de empuxo lateral de serviço (Ks) apresentou-se menor quanto maior a 

tensão efetiva vertical e quanto menor a densidade relativa da areia. 

O solo não fluidizado apresentou o mesmo valor de resistência nos ensaios realizados 

imediatamente e 24 horas após a cravação. Esta constatação refletiu os baixos níveis de 

tensões de confinamento, onde os efeitos de setup em laboratório não são acentuados, pois a 

dissipação das poropressões ocorre rapidamente e o efeito de quebra dos grãos (crushing) é 

minimizado.  

O solo fluidizado apresentou ganho de capacidade de carga com tempo de 24 horas 

após a instalação (efeito de setup). O processo de ganho de resistência foi relacionado com a 

dissipação das poropressões geradas pelo jateamento e o rearranjo/reacomodação dos grãos na 

cavidade perturbada/erodida no entorno do fuste da estaca após o término da fluidização.  

Tanto os resultados de instalação por fluidização, quanto os resultados de capacidade 

de carga não apresentaram influência dos efeitos de fronteira, ou seja, relação entre as 

dimensões do tanque e dimensões do modelo de estaca (D/de), como também os efeitos de 

escala relacionados aos diferentes diâmetros de estacas e o diâmetro do grão de areia (de/d50) 

não foram observados e identificados nos ensaios.  

Os resultados dos ensaios desta pesquisa forneceram uma base consistente de dados, 

dentro do intervalo de escalas trabalhadas. Tais resultados auxiliam no entendimento da 

influência de diferentes parâmetros na instalação e no arrancamento de estacas em solo 

fluidizado e não fluidizado. Ainda assim, os parâmetros de instalação e de arrancamento 

obtidos devem ser considerados preliminares, sendo que estudos em modelos maiores 

(emprego de menores fatores de escala de comprimento ?L) e tensões de confinamento mais 

elevadas são necessários para melhor avaliá-los, antes do emprego em projetos de engenharia 

offshore. 

 

 

 



155 
Capítulo 6 – Conclusões 

 

Instalação e Capacidade de Carga Axial de Estacas Modelo Fluidizadas em Solos Arenosos 

6.4 Sugestões para pesquisas futuras 

Para trabalhos futuros de fluidização em solos arenosos, as sugestões são: 

? Instalação de modelos com variação da vazão e velocidade de jateamento dentro do 

mesmo ensaio de instalação (multi estágios); 

? Aplicação inicial da vazão e velocidade de jateamento e leitura de suas variações 

durante a instalação dos modelos; 

? Aplicação de velocidade constante de instalação por fluidização (controle de 

cravação); 

? Execução de provas de carga à tração axial com controle de deslocamentos; 

? Utilização de estacas com diferente rugosidade superficial; 

? Utilização de outras granulometrias para areia uniforme; 

? Utilização de pluviometria para preenchimento do tanque de ensaios; 

? Aumento das tensões de confinamento;  

? Aumento dos modelos (emprego de um menor fator escala de comprimento ?L) para 

ensaios de estacas em laboratório; 

? Aplicação técnica DIC (Digital Image Correlation) para ensaios na face do tanque, 

visando o aprofundamento no conhecimento sobre os mecanismos, comportamento e 

geometria da zona fluidizada; 

? Utilização de sensores de pressão dentro da amostra de solo posicionados em 

diferentes profundidades e distâncias do fuste das estacas;  

? Estudo do fluxo radial entre as zonas fluidizada e não fluidizada;  

? Análise do equilíbrio de forças atuantes no modelo de estaca durante o processo de 

instalação por fluidização do solo;  

? Execução de testes in situ em modelos.

LARISSA DE BRUM PASSINI 1 

 

1. Introduction 

According to White & Bolton (2004), the mechanisms governing the behavior of displacement piles in sand 

are not well understood. The axial capacity of displacement piles in sand is arguably the subject of greatest 

uncertainty in geotechnical engineering. The literature on estimation of the uplift load capacity of piles is 

limited (e.g. Vesic, 1967, 1970; Sowa, 1970; Meyerhof, 1973; Das & Seeley, 1975; Das et al., 1976, 1977; 

Das, 1983; Levacher & Sieffert, 1984; Rao & Venkatesh, 1985; Chattopadhyay & Pise, 1986; Alawneh et al., 

1999; Gavin & Lehane, 2003; Shanker et al., 2007; Loukidis & Salgado, 2008; Basu & Salgado, 2012). 

Therefore, the experimental methodology that has been adopted at Bowen Laboratory to study the sand 

soil displacement field around the pile penetration and pullout on sand sample is by axisymmetric 

boundary conditions using a half-circular model and a transparent observation window. The methodology 

is based on the DIC (Digital Image Correlation) technique. The digital image correlation (DIC) technique is a 

non-contact optical method employed in experimental mechanics to obtain full-field surface displacements 

of a specimen during a loading event.  

The basic principle of DIC is that the area of interest in the reference image is divided into a virtual grid. 

The spacing of the grid defines the measurement resolution. The displacement calculations are made at 

each node of the grid by tracking the same points (pixels) from the reference image to that in the 

deformed image. The displacement vector of a subset is obtained from the difference between the 

coordinates of the centers of the subset in the original configuration and the corresponding subset in the 

deformed configuration as determined using a peak correlation algorithm (e.g. Cintron, 2008).  

The digital image correlation requires computer software (VIC-2D) and an appropriate digital camera. To 

get accurate measurements with this technique it is important to consider some variables (e.g. Cintron, 

2008). Various parametric experiments were performed for assessing the accuracy of DIC correlation 

algorithms, and key parameters influencing the accuracy of DIC analysis results were identified and they 

were optimized, being the effect of refraction, lens distortion, illumination, particle disappearance from 

view and glass scratching. Arshad et al. (2014) built the test chamber at Bowen Laboratory and took care of 

the equipments setup, optimization of the parameters that influence the DIC analysis, cameras and 

softwares.  

Studies of White & Bolton (2003, 2004), Cintron (2008) and Arshad et al. (2014) provide guidance on the 

calculation of data on the values of three single piles tested by digital image correlation DIC. 

White & Bolton (2004) used digital images to measure soil displacement around the pile during monotonic 

jacking into silica and carbonate sands. They conducted a series of plane strain calibration chamber tests in 

order to quantify the penetration mechanism around the pile tip, and the response of the interface layer 

adjacent to the shaft during further penetration. It was found the displacement and strain paths are 

relatively independent of soil type.  

According Arshad et al. (2014), the results of DIC analyses and measured cone resistance suggest that the 

soil displacement around an advancing cone depends on the density and crushability of the sand, as well as 

the depth of penetration. The displacements obtained from the DIC technique are, in general, close 

estimates of the displacements that would be observed in the real problem.

2.  Materials and equipments 

The silica sand used in the tests presented sub-angular grain shape, particle size (d50) of 0.65 mm, specific 

density (Gs) of 2.65, and maximum (emax) and minimum (emin) voids ratio of 0.853 and 0.537, respectively. 

The sand named Ohio Gold Frac presented critical angle (?cv) of 36.4° and coefficient of uniformity (Cu) 

equal to 1.37 and silicon dioxide (SiO2) = 99.7% (Arshad et al., 2014). The sand (Figure 2.1) was artificially 

colored in order to facilitate the DIC test, once it is indispensable to get a good speckle pattern in order to 

have success of measurements with VIC-2D (e.g. Cintron, 2008).The speckle pattern can be naturally 

occurring or can be applied as in this study. 

 

Figure 2.1. Sand 

 

The pile used in this tests presented diameter of 31.75 mm, been a half-circular rod section with 915 mm 

long, and a half-section conical tip with a 60° apex angle attached. The material of the pile was brass with 

smooth surface. The frictional angle between the pile and the sand (?) was adopted equal to 0.65?cv or 

23.66°. 

The interface friction angle ? is expressed in terms of the critical state friction angle (?cv = 36.4
o
) for the 

fine sand (e.g. Salgado, 2005, 2008; Velloso & Lopes, 2010; Basu et al., 2011; Basu & Salgado, 2012). This 

assumption is justified by the very large vertical shear strains developed near the pile shaft at ultimate load 

levels, expressed in terms of the constant-volume (or critical-state) friction angle (e.g. Lehane et al., 1993; 

Jardine & Chow, 1996; Jardine et al., 1992, 1998; Alawneh et al., 1999; Loukidis & Salgado, 2008). The 

interface friction angle is also a function of the interface material and its roughness (e.g. Potoyndy, 1961; 

Kulhawy et al., 1983 Fioravante, 2002; Colombi, 2005; Lehane et al., 2005, 2012) and the pile type (Yang et 

al., 2010). Kishida & Uesugi (1987) and Lehane et al. (2012) reported that sand interface shearing angles 

are controlled by the ratio of the interface roughness R to the median grain size d50, up to the limit ? = ?cv. 

The value adopted for ? is comparable to values proposed by Potts & Martins (1982), Lehane et al. (1993), 

Alawneh et al. (1999, 2003), Paik & Salgado (2003), Patra & Pise (2003), Shanker (2006); Shanker et al. 

(2007), Salgado (2008), Shelke & Mishra (2010), Yang et al. (2010) as well as with recommendations by the 

American Petroleum Institute code of practice (API RP 2A, 1991). 



  FINAL REPORT – PURDUE UNIVERSITY 

 

LARISSA DE BRUM PASSINI 3 

 

The half-circular steel chamber was used in the present research with three observation windows, which 

allowed imaging of the half-circular pile and the surrounding soil during the installation and pullout tests. 

The tank presented a diameter of 1680 mm and a height of 1200 mm.  

The size of the half-circular calibration chamber and half-circular pile were chosen in order to minimize 

boundary and scale effects and the sand particle size was chosen in order to allow the analyses from the 

images taken using the DIC (Digital Image Correlation) technique. The ratio between the tank and the pile 

diameter (D/de) was 52.91 and the ratio between the pile and the sand (de/d50) was 48.84. 

The jacking system (with 50 kN capacity) consisted of two screw jacks with a dedicated motor controller 

was used to perform the pile tests at a constant displacement rate, range from 0 to 100 = 0 to 0.69 mm/s. 

Two velocities were applied during the push and pull out tests, being 20 (0.12 mm/s) and 100 (0.69 mm/s). 

The instrumentation sensors consisted for: i) two pressure sensors (Figure 2.2a), positioned on the sand 

next to the pile shaft in two different depths (top and center of the sample, around 55 and 380 mm from 

surface). The capacity of the top and tip pressure sensor was 200 kPa and 1 MPa, respectively. ii) three load 

cells, one positioned on the bottom of the tank (Figure 2.2b) and two positioned on the pile, been 

nominated the top (Figure 2.2c) and tip (Figure 2.2d) load cells with capacity of 20 kN and 10 kN, 

respectively. iii) one linear position sensor/potentiometer (Figure 2.2e) to measure the displacement of the 

pile with range of 640 mm.  

Base boundary effects were monitored during testing by the tank load cell installed in the sample at the 

base of the chamber along the pile penetration path. Lateral boundary effects were monitored by the two 

miniature pressure transducers installed at two mid-height into the sample.

? The procedure to fill the tank followed activities described below:   

A new clear, annealed glass sheet (Figure 3.1a) was fixed behind the three windows (Figure 3.1b) every 

test, using three different types of tapes (masking tape, duct tape and Packaging tape). The sand sample 

was prepared by air pluviation using a large pluviator (# 9.95 mm) with a sieve (# 3.2 mm) attached (Figure 

3.1c) in order to obtain a uniform dense sand (DR=90%). Without the sieve would obtain medium sand. The 

amount of sand necessary to fulfill the tank was positioned and stored in six bags (Figure 3.1d) beside the

4. Description of the tests 

Three pullout tests were performed in order to evaluate the influence of installation process on the pile 

shaft capacity, being all displacement piles. The tests were performed with a surcharge of 70 kPa and in 

dense sand (DR = 90%). A general view from pullout test is showed at Figure 4.1a, as well the pile displaced 

detail at Figure 4.1b.

All tests had their particularities and they are described below. The main modification between the first 

and the second test was during the stage 1, jacking installation with different number of strokes. The third 

test was longer and with more stages, including driving with hammer and two rest periods (setup) before 

the pullout test. The installed depth of the piles were 435.4 mm, 436.5 mm and 457.2 mm, respectively at 

first, second and third test. The ratio between the pile length and diameter (L/de) were 13.71, 13.74 and 

14.40 in the same order. The ratio between the pile final length and its radius (L/rc) were 27.43, 27.49 and 

28.80.  

 

1st) Pullout test 

The pile passed through 7(seven) stages in the total, starting on 01.10.2014 and finishing on 09.10.2014. 

Stage 1 – Installation by Jacking with Strokes. In this stage, the pile was pushed 20 mm at a rate of 0.69 

mm/s, held for 10 seconds and pulled up until the top load cell be reseted (read zero). Once the sensor of 

the top load cell read zero, it was waited 15 seconds and the procedure was repeated, until the installation 

deep of 400 mm (20 times). In the end of the installation, the top load cell was disconnected and 

reconnected to simulate the conclusion of the stage. Test on 01.10.2014. 

Stage 2 - Static Load Test First. Immediately after the stage 1, the pile was pushed 0.1D = 3.175 mm at a 

rate of 0.12 mm/s. Test on 01.10.2014. 

Stage 3 - Cyclic Test. Immediately after the stage 2, the pile was pushed and pulled 0.05D (1 cycle). A total 

of 20 cycles were executed at a rate of 0.12 mm/s. Test on 01.10.2014. 

Stage 4 - Static Load Test Second. Immediately after the stage 3, the pile was pushed 0.1D = 3.175 mm at a 

rate of 0.12 mm/s. Test on 01.10.2014.

5. DIC from VIC-2D 

The commercial digital image correlation DIC software "VIC - 2D" from Correlated Solutions was used for 

processing the images taken during the pullout tests. A video (animation) from a sequence a photos during 

the test with horizontal displacements (Figure 5.1a) and vertical displacements (Figure 5.1b), horizontal 

strain (Figure 5.2a), vertical strain (Figure 5.2b) and shear strains (Figure 5.2c) could be obtained from this 

processing. The data could be exported to excel with the available variables:  

•  x [pixel] – x location of the point in the image (in pixels)  

•  y [pixel] – y location of the point in the image (in pixels)  

•  u [pixel] – x (horizontal) displacement of this point (in pixels)  

•  v [pixel] – y (vertical) displacement of this point(in pixels)  

•  sigma [pixel] – the confidence interval for the match location (in pixels)  

•  exx [1] – the strain in X  

•  eyy [1] – the strain in Y  

•  exy [1] – the shear strain  

•  e1 [1] – the major principal strain  

•  e2 [1] – the minor principal strain  

•  gamma [1] – the principal strain angle, in radians

To start the analyses, the (i) images taken from Camera 2 (center window), where the pile tip is located, 

were uploaded into the software installed in a computer with a key code to allow to run the program, (ii) 

the reference image was selected, in which all strains and displacements will be relative to this image, (iii) 

the area of interest (AOI) in the picture was selected, and (iv) the subset of 35 and step size of 5 for the AOI 

were selected. The subset size controls the size of the DIC analysis window and is displayed in the size of 

the yellow seed point box; this should be at least as big as your smallest speckle. The default works well 

most tests. The step size controls the density of analyzed data; a step size of 5 will analyze every 5
th

 point in 

each direction. A higher step size gives faster results but coarser data. A smaller step size will return more 

points but will take longer.  

In sequence, (v) three initial guess points were manually introduced from the reference image to the 

deformed image; (vi) the calibrate for scale was introduced, from the known distance between two points, 

previously marked on the glass, being equal 304.8 mm. Therefore, each camera in each test had one 

calibration scale that converts pixel in mm. (vii) In order to run the analyses, all pictures were selected. In 

options, it was chosen exhaustive search, low-pass filter images and incremental correlation. In post-

processing, it was selected strain computation and compute principal strains. Once the analysis was done, 

the data were exported, in file format of “comma separated variables” (Figure 5.3). Data entries were 

separated by commas. This format is understood by most spreadsheet programs and plotting packages. 

Variable names were stored in the data file as comma separated strings in quotation marks.  The manuals 

provided online by Correlated Solutions were very helpful to allow the program manipulation correctly.

6. Tests results  

 

? Sensors: 

The tests started with the piles under compression, as can be seen at the curves load versus displacement 

(Figures 6.1 to 6.3), because of the last stage of pushing that the pile suffered before the pullout test. The 

tank load cell read maximum values when the pile was under compression. Once the pile was relieved, 

those values decrease and during the pullout they became constant.  

The top pressure sensor installed on soil read almost constant values during the tests. However, the tip 

pressure sensor also installed on soil read high values when the pile was under compression and once the 

pile started to be pulled out, the values decreased and became constant. Unfortunately, during the third 

test, the pressure sensors did not work properly. The sensors results showed the surcharge values were 

constant during the tests. The behavior of the sensors (tank load cell, top pressure, tip pressure and 

surcharge) versus displacement during the pullout tests can be seen at Figure 6.4. No boundary conditions 

interfering during in the pullout tests. The sensors results are summarized at Table 6.1.

The axial capacity (Qf) of the pile during the pullout was 2425.4 N, 1819.1 N and 2615.8 N and the total 

displacement (w) at the break (fail) was equal to 7.1 mm, 6.6 mm and 7.2 mm, respectively for first, second 

and third test. The first test presented greater axial capacity than second test because of its suffered more 

and short strokes during the jacking at the installation process (e.g Foray et al., 2010; Basu et al., 2011). As 

it was expected, the third pullout test presented greater axial capacity over all, since during the pile 

installation it’s suffered hammer blows and also had two rest periods (setup).  

Lim & Lehane (2014) showed from their laboratory tension load tests results, a clear and consistent trend 

for driven piles to have larger shaft capacities than monotonically jacked piles. Although the experiments 

accomplished by the authors showed that rate of capacity gain with time for the driven piles is generally 

higher than that of the jacked piles, this trend is less obvious than seen in the field by Lim (2013), who 

found much higher relative increases in capacity with time for the driven piles. The average ultimate shaft 

frictions mobilized by buried piles at the laboratory before and after rested was similar. The observed 

change was clearly negligible compared to changes observed for the displacement piles (driven and 

jacked), indicating that setup must be due to the disturbance induced during pile installation in their 

studies. 

According to York et al. (1994); Tan et al. (2004); Yan & Yuen (2010) and Steward & Wang (2011), in 

geotechnical engineering practice, the increase of pile capacity after installation is known as pile setup. Pile 

setup is the phenomenon of the increase of pile capacity over time (Axelsson, 1998; Axelsson & Westin, 

2000; Foray et al., 2010 and Lim & Lehane, 2014), during and after the dissipation of pore pressure and the 

stabilization of lateral earth pressure.  

This phenomenon is definitely favorable to engineering designs, such as in many important practical 

implications concerning testing methods, the programming of foundation construction, and the 

reassessment of existing driven pile capacities. Increase in pile capacity after initial driving has been well 

observed in clays and sands over decades. Chow et al. (1998) complement that much uncertainty 

surrounds the factors responsible for these changes and these changes in the stress regimes created during 

pile driving are probably responsible for the observed setup.  



  FINAL REPORT – PURDUE UNIVERSITY 

 

LARISSA DE BRUM PASSINI 17 

 

However, recent evidence (e.g. Yamamuro et al., 1996; Lade, 2007; Lade et al., 1997, 2009, 2010; Lade & 

Karimpour, 2010; Karimpour & Lade, 2010; Yang et al., 2010; Lim & Lehane,2014) appears to show that 

setup in sand is closely related to particle crushing. When the stresses on soil particles exceed their 

strengths, particle breakage occurs. Very little crushing occurs at low confining pressures, while 

experiments show that considerable crushing occurs at higher confining pressures where the time effects 

are also pronounced. The amount of crushing relates to the amount of energy input to the soil. Thus, time 

effects are related to energy input and crushing.  

Because of the explanation above it were included different types of installation and rest time in the tests. 

However, these effects could not be observed clearly, since all three tests presented similar behavior and 

results. 

Generally, an equation that is usually used to evaluate the net ultimate uplift side resistance of a vertical 

circular pile in sand:

Where Ks is the coefficient of lateral earth pressure (ratio of horizontal to vertical normal effective stress), 

?'v is the effective overburden stress, ? is the interface friction angle between soil and pile shaft, and As is 

the lateral area of the pile.  

The coefficient of lateral earth pressure Ks is an important factor that needs to be determined, as reported 

by Alawneh et al. (1999) and Salgado (2005). Ks depends on the initial relative density and confining stress 

of the soil (thus on the original in situ at rest lateral earth pressure coefficient Ko) (e.g., Basu et al., 2011), 

as well as the properties of the surrounding soil, the method of pile installation, the number of blows or 

jacking strokes (if driving or jacking are used to install the pile), and the mode of loading (e.g. Meyerhof, 

1956; Broms, 1964; Peck et al., 1974; Poulos, 1989; Kraft, 1991; Alawneh et al., 1999; Shanker et al., 2007, 

Shelke & Mishra, 2010, Lim & Lehane, 2014). 

Considering the effective overburden stress (?'v) at the average depth of the pile installed, including the 

surcharge of 70 kPa, for relative density of 90% and the lateral area (As) of half pile (1/2.?.de.L), since the 

pile used presented a half-circular rod section, the coefficient of lateral earth pressure (Ks) obtained for 

each test is equal to 3.464, 2.591 and 3.549, respectively. The product Kstan? is sometimes denoted by ?, 

named shaft friction coefficient (Loukidis & Salgado, 2008; Basu et al., 2011), being equal to 1.517, 1.135 

and 1.555 for each test (Table 6.2). These values are in accordance with submitted by Loukidis & Salgado 

(2008).

? DIC: 

It was selected 4 (four) different moments of the pullout test to be graphed. It means that a total of 5 (five) 

images (including the initial picture) and their data file were worked for each test. The displacement w 

adopted to be graph was relative to the pile radius rc, being equal to 2 mm = 0.125rc (when the pile tip is 

free), 7.1 mm; 6.6 mm and 7.2 mm = 0.447rc, 0.415rc and 0.453rc (when the pile failed during the pullout 

test), 11.90 mm = 0.75rc and 15.875mm = 1.0rc.  

According to White & Bolton (2004), the pile tip rebound during unloading of a field pile might typically be 

equal to 1 or 2 mm. Test results corroborate this affirmative by combine the data of the load and 

displacement sensors. So, the first image selected to the graph was the one that represents 2 mm of 

displacement.   

The sand horizontal and vertical displacement and the pile depth position were normalized by the pile 

radius, being u/rc, v/rc and z/rc, respectively. The distances r/rc from the pile shaft adopted in order to show 

the sand horizontal and vertical displacement results were equal to 1.0 until 7.0. For sand displacement 

vectors results were adopted maximum r/rc equal to 6.0 and for strain results it wasn’t necessary r/rc more 

than equal to 2.0. A similar normalization values were adopted by Arshad et al. (2014). 

The results from the first pullout test are presented at Figures 6.5 to 6.10, from the second pullout test are 

presented at Figures 6.11 to 6.16 and from the third pullout test are presented at Figures 6.17 to 6.22. All 

results are total (absolute), it means that the sand displacements and strains graphed are not incremental. 

All three tests presented similar behavior and results. The values obtained are in accordance with 

submitted by Arshad et al. (2014). 

The sand horizontal displacement is greater close the pile tip, since the pile is going up and an empty space 

is created. The sand vertical displacement is greater close to the pile shaft due to the ascendant movement 

of the sand around the model length. The sand displacement vectors combine the horizontal and vertical 

displacements. The scale adopted for displacement vectors were necessary to allow the visualization of the 

arrows. The shear strain is the main result obtained during the pile pullout capacity test, due to the shear 

band formed around the model length. The horizontal and vertical strains have secondary importance. The 

values of horizontal and vertical displacement, displacement vectors, as well as the shear strain, horizontal 

and vertical strain increase as the pile displacement is increased.

7. Conclusion 

The results presented in this report provide detailed experimental evidence of the mechanisms of a 

displacement pile during axial uplift request. The digital image correlation DIC software Vic-2D is able to 

provide logical and useful displacement and strain maps to show the behavior of the granular soil during 

the deformation process. The system is capable to detect the areas with higher strains inside the area of 

interest. The acquired knowledge was of great value during the student passage at Purdue University and 

will be disseminated at Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul – geotechnical engineering program, in 

order to add the technique in their researches.

Regular Paper

On the response of fluidized piles from
laboratory model tests in granular soils

F. Schnaid?, L. Passini, F. Stracke and S. Mezzomo
Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil

Abstract. Design guidelines of foundation anchors and piles embedded in fluidized sand comprises understanding of installation
processes, defining constitutive parameters and establishing analysis techniques. These fundamental aspects have been inves-
tigated by a series of laboratory model tests designed to evaluate the mechanism taking place during pile installation through
the influence of downwardly-directed vertical water jets in the geometry of fluidized cavities in saturated sands. Measurements
indicate fluidization geometry to be controlled by combined effects of jet velocity and the ratio of particle and jet diameters
which can be conveniently expressed by the Froude number of particles. Characteristics of the fluidized zone geometry prior
and after fluidization indicate considerable reduction of relative density of fluidized samples. Limit equilibrium analysis using
geotechnical parameters approaching critical state provided indicative horizontal stress levels to estimate the uplift skin friction
of model steel piles.

Keywords: Fluidization, sands, piles

1. Introduction

Fluidization is defined as the suspension of particles due to the action of an upward fluid flow. General principles
and mechanisms of fluidization in granular soils have been comprehensively analysed and have given rise to a
number of applications in the field of channelling [23, 32, 33], erosion [1], removal of sediments and remediation
of contaminants (e.g. [3, 6, 22, 24]). Despite being a common feature in several disciplines, the application of
fluidization processes to foundation engineering is not well understood and possible applications have not been fully
explored. Although empirical approaches provide valuable insights for onshore, nearshore and offshore foundations
(e.g. [4, 9, 11]), there is no standardized design methodology. Under current configurations, there is scope to provide
recommendations to optimise the jetting performance by verifying some of the essential features of the fluidization
process that occurs as a jet is lowered into a granular medium. Implications of the fluidization process to piles
analysis and design are discussed on the light of critical state soil mechanics.

2. Materials and methods

Fluidization, piezocone and load tests were carried out in rectangular acrylic chambers with internal dimensions
of 478 mm × 278 mm × 320 mm and 450 mm × 450 mm × 1100 mm high (Fig. 1a, c). Siliceous sand specimen
prepared using the moist tamping method were carefully inundated by water percolating upwards until it reaches a
water constant head of 5 cm above the soil surface. It is then maintained constant throughout the test to ensure that
the flow rate and therefore the jet velocity are constant.

70 F. Schnaid et al. / On the response of fluidized piles from laboratory model tests in granular soils

Fig. 1. Details of (a, c) fluidization chambers, (b) supporting frame and (d) metal tubes.

To start the test, a metal tube is positioned vertically on the soil surface, being lowered in increments during
the jetting stage. Carbon steel metal tubes have been used with internal diameters ranging from 3.85 mm to 12 mm
(Fig. 1d). A downwardly-directed vertical water jet velocity is applied through the tubes and at the end of each
stage, after completion of the fluidization process, the tube is repositioned in increasing depths within the chamber.
A supporting structure equipped with a ball-screw allowed the gradual displacement of the tubes at any location
below the sand surface in a precise upright position (Fig. 1b). The descent of the tubes is conducted in 20 mm
increments along the depth.

A schematic representation of the experimental setup is presented in Fig. 2. The hydraulic circuit consists on a
PVC pipeline where the water from a 500 litter’s reservoir flows driven by a centrifugal pump. The pump motor is
connected to a frequency inverter, which regulates the rotation speed of the pump and thus the flow rate, measured
by a rotameter. The insertion tubes are the final part of the circuit. The water produces a jet emanating from the
tubes that fluidizes the soil zone when inserted inside the sand.

The tubes installed into the soil were later used as prototype piles to perform load tests using the steel casing
attached to the chamber as a reaction frame. A seating load varying from 1 to 7 N (corresponding to the actual
weight of the pile) was applied prior to zeroing the dial gauges and additional load was then applied in small
increments ranging from 10 to 15 percent of the design load and maintained for a few minutes (necessary for
complete stabilization of displacements).

Two sands have been tested, corresponding to the fine and coarse particle size distribution shown in Fig. 3. The
fine sand comes from a natural deposit located in Brazil (Osorio Sand), while the coarse sand is a material selected

obtained by deposition inside the acrylic box at relative densities of 50% and 90%.

For tests carried out in the present study, for each depth, the tube was held in a fixed position and measurements of
the fluidized zone geometry were recorded. After completion of each stage, the tube was lowered and the procedure
repeated. Experiments were conducted with the jet positioned in the centre of the tank and adjacent to the tank wall
for observation purposes. In this last case, the geometric information was obtained by direct observation through the
walls of the acrylic tank covered with a plastic film to allow tracing of fluidized contours of the cavity. In addition
experiments have been photographed and filmed.

For any given sand, three groups of tests have been carried out as outlined below.

a) Constant flow rate (Qo) with variations in the injection diameter (dj ) and jet velocity (Uo)
b) Constant jet velocity (Uo) with variations in the injection diameter (dj ) and flow rate (Qo)
c) Constant injection diameter (dj ) with variations in jet velocity (Uo) and flow rate (Qo)

Controlled variables are the injection diameter (dj ), that is the same of the internal pile diameter (di), external pile
diameter (de), pile length inside sand specimen (L), sand physical properties, water height above the soil (hw) and
the dimensions of the tank. Measured parameters are the flow rate (Qo), temperature of the water and the geometry
of the steady state fluidized zone which is all represented in Fig. 4. A series of 63 tests in lateral position inside the
tank was carried out to evaluate the influence of flow rate in the range of 0.70 and 6.80 L/min and jet velocity in the
range 0.13 to 4.29 m/s, as summarized in Table 2. Since the viscosity of the water is affected by temperature, the
water temperature was kept constant at 20

The geometry of the fluidized zone after completion of the test procedure is presented in Fig. 5a. During fluidization

a steady state profile is formed exhibiting a concave upward sharp interface between fluidized and surrounding non-
fluidized soil. The interface contour is drawn as a continuous line, with a vertical dashed line representing the axis
of penetration of the jet and the dotted line the original sand surface. In this set of experiments a fully axisymmetric

into the sand, and as a consequence the depths and radii of the fluidized zone are different in fine and coarse sand.

No boundary effects have been observed for the tested geometries, as demonstrated by experiments carried out
with piles in different tanks provided the minimum distance between the pile and the tank wall exceeds 20de. The

radial flow percolates through the sand and may occasionally reach the boundaries, flowing upwards and out the
tank, without affecting the actual geometry of the fluidized sand.

Direct observation of the measured steady state geometries indicates that, for a given sand and constant input
parameters, the increase in flow rate leads to increasing dH and a values. For a given flow, the diameter of the
fluidized zone reduces with increasing average particle diameter (D50 or dp). As for the jet velocity, for a given
sand and flow rate, the larger the diameter of the jet (dj ) the lower the radii of the fluidized zone at the jet tip
dH and the jet penetration depth a. Consequently, as the jet velocity increases the diameter of the fluidized zone
and the jet penetration depth also increase. The soil movement due to turbulent flow under high jet velocities
extended up to 20 pile diameters from the side of the prototype piles and up to 30 diameters below the pile tip. The
geometry of the fluidized zone reported here is representative of tubes fixed vertically and lowered into the ground
in increments during the jet stage: this condition differs from piles lowered into the ground by the own self-weight
during fluidization (to be addressed in a separate publication).

4. Fluidized geometry

Results are interpreted on the bases of the geometrical parameters defined in Fig. 4, emphasizing the two param-
eters that control pile design: jet penetration depth a and diameter of fluidized zone at the pile tip dH . Tests on fine
sand are grouped in Fig. 6 and are used to illustrate the experimental testing conditions for different combinations
of pile diameters, jet velocity and relative density. As seen in this figure both a and dH remained approximately
constant throughout the test, demonstrating that scour geometries can be conveniently scaled by the pile diameter
dj . Tests on coarse sand exhibit the same behavioural patter described for fine sand, with a slightly reduction in
a/dj and dH /dj as the jet depth approaches that of a cavity formation, at the critical depth.

Tests carried out in a given sand (fine, medium or course) and at a given jet velocity (Uo) can be expressed by
the Froude number of particles (Frp), according to Equation 1. The variation of a/dj versus Frp is plotted in Fig. 7,
showing average data points corresponding to stable open profiles for a variety of fine and coarse sands, including
data reported by Niven, 1998. In all sands the fluidization jet penetration depth a/dj increases with increasing Frp.
By multiple regression analysis, the value of a/dj can be correlated to Frp by polynomial function:

There has been no influence of relative density in the geometry of the fluidized zone when the two governing
parameters: jet penetration depth a and radii at the pile tip dH are plotted in the Frp space.

In general terms, experiments have confirmed previous research, indicating the transition from an open to a
submerged fluidized cavity. This transition occurs at a critical depth T that appears to be a complex function of the
ability of the flow to support the weight of the overlaying fluidized bed, the turbulent nature of the scour process
and the permeability of the surrounding soil [13, 22].

In the present study the critical depth has been clearly observed in experiments on coarse [20] and fine sands
[30]. Measured critical depths comply with previously values reported by Niven [21]. The critical depth is shown
to be a function of the flow rate Qo, injection diameter dj and jet velocity Uo, particle diameter dp and coefficient
of hydraulic conductivity k (to be addressed in a separate publication).

5. Sand density

Once the prediction of steady state fluidized zone geometry from system variables is completed, the additional
requirement for foundation design is the density of the fluidized area after completion of fluidized cycle. During
fluidization, the granular particles are subjected to an upward fluid flow which creates a drag force sufficient to
support the weight of the particles [16]. Once the jet is halted, viscous and kinetic energy is lost, a general slope failure
occurs and closures the fluidized bed. Consequently, the density of the fluidized area prior and after fluidization is
expected to change.

Cone penetrometer test (CPT) characterization of the two sands used in these tests allowed density to be estimated
prior and after fluidization. CPT results are presented in terms of the variation of tip cone resistance qc with depth
measured with a 8 mm diameter minicone (0.5 cm2 cross section area) for tests carried out in fine and coarse,
fluidized and non-fluidized sand (Fig. 9). In fine sand, the qc values for both medium and dense samples increase
linearly with depth. The relative density (Dr) of the undisturbed denser sand is of about 90%, corresponding to
qc = 680 kPa at the mid-height of sample in the centre of the tank, and reduces to qc = 250 kPa for a medium density
of 50%. After fluidization the cone resistance reduces to an average value of about qc = 125 kPa for both samples
(dense and medium initial densities), which corresponds to fluidizeds and densities of about 30%.

Similar results have been obtained for coarse sand, as indicated by the measurements of cone resistance qc for
medium dense samples (Fig. 9b). The coarse sand produces profiles with many small sharp peaks and troughs
due to the large size of grains in respect to the diameter of the cone. The initial measured relative density of 50%

corresponds to the maximum jet penetration depth and, therefore, below this depth the fluidized and non-fluidized

Boundary conditions would have to be considered when predicting relative density from penetration measure-

densities, the relative density (Dr) of these tested sands is related to the CPT qc values by equation 4:

6. Implications to design

The shaft friction developed on displacement piles is related to the degree of soil displacement imparted during pile
installation. Factors to be considered in the development of shaft friction prediction methods are radial effective stress
at failure, interface friction angle between the soil and pile, type and number of cycles imposed during drivability,
mode of loading, among others (e.g. [5, 19, 25, 26]). Because of the shortage of high quality measurements of
shaft friction on tension jacked steel piles and the lack of consistent data on fluidization piles, the analysis of the
potential implications of the fluidization process to foundation design is investigated in the present work by a series
of tension load tests carried out in fine sands.

The work comprises 90 tests in hydraulic displacement piles (jacked piles), immediately and 24 hours after pile
driven, and 36 tests in fluidized piles, by suspended tubes and piles lowered into the ground by the own self-weight
during fluidization, 24 hours after pile installation, both in the center position inside the tank. The testing programme
described in Table 3 corresponds to tests performed in fine sand with initial sand density of 50% and 90%. Loads
were applied in stages and increased up to failure, as illustrated by the typical results of load-displacement curves
shown in Fig. 10. Being load control, tests provide reliable and accurate measurements of maximum loads but do
not allow brittle post-peak behavior to be detected, particularly for piles in denser sand. The uplift displacement-to-
diameter ratios at failure are of the order of 0.01% and at this stage the maximum load characterizes the pile shaft
uplift capacity, Qf .

A possible reason for foundations submitted to tensile loading presenting displacements that are smaller than
those with the same compressive load is that shear strains under uplift loading are more pronounced than volumetric
strains in contributing to displacements. In the case of fine sand, the combination of pile roughness (smooth pile)
and the fine grain size produces a thin shear band at the soil-pile interface, thus yielding to very small displacements
to reach failure conditions. Coarse sand, specially for dilative interface, would exhibit distinct pile response.

In this set of experiments it has been observed that, for each relative density, values of Qf measured immediately
and 24 hours after pile installation in non-fluidized soil remained unchanged, as expected, since the material has
high permeability and fast dissipation of initial excess pore pressures. The impact of the fluidization process on
overall shaft capacity is considerable, reflecting the changes in sand density (Dr). In addition, given to the laws of
similarity, values of Qf are shown to be dependent on pile diameter (de) and length (L) and independent from flow
rate (Qo), as demonstrated in Fig. 11 (a, b and c).

One simplifying assumption in the interpretation of these model pile tests is to assume ?f constant over the pile
shaft for both fluidized and non-fluidized piles. The effective vertical stress corresponds to the overburden stress,
despite the fact that in sand unit shaft resistance does not necessarily increase linearly with depth (e.g. [15, 31]).

For the fine sand, the interface friction angle ? is assumed to be the same as the critical state friction angle
(?cv = 26.6

?
), as obtained from triaxial and ring shear tests conducted by Consoli et al. [7]. The assumption of

? = ?cv is justified by the very large vertical shear strains developed near the pile shaft at ultimate load levels,
expressed in terms of the constant-volume (or critical-state) friction angle (e.g. [17, 18]). It is supported by direct
interface shear tests [14, 17] and in close agreement to recommendations from by the American Petroleum Institute
code of practice [2].

Within these assumptions, the average coefficient of lateral earth pressure Ks for each test is calculated using
equation 6 (Fig. 12a, b and c) for fluidized and non-fluidized fine sand. Ks values at full mobilisation of limit shaft
resistance are shown to increase with increasing sand relative density and decrease with increasing initial effective
overburden stress. At higher stresses (i.e. longer piles) Ks values become relatively constant, reaching minimum of
0.15, 0.30 and 0.50 for fluidized, non-fluidized Dr = 50% and non-fluidized Dr = 90% sand specimens, respectively.
These measured values of Ks are slightly lower than early reported data and yield Ks/K0 ratios of the order of 1.0 and
2.0 for non-fluidized sand at 50% e 90% respectively (e.g. [28]). Maximum Ks values order of 1.5 in non-fluidized
sand (Ks/K0 ?4.5) and have been obtained and very low confining stresses.

Although grain size effects become negligible for de/d50 larger than 100 to 200 [8, 10], these calculated values
should be considered as preliminary indications of Ks and further validation in larger model scales is necessary
before their use in engineering design.

Fig. 12. Coefficient of lateral earth pressure (Ks) versus pile length inside sand specimen (L) in (a) fluidized (b, c) non-fluidized fine sand.

7. Conclusions

This paper reports results from small scale laboratory model tests carried out to investigate the mechanisms of
pile installation in fluidized sands. Considering that the research aims at supporting the prediction the geometry
and density of fluidized cavities for future use in foundation design, attention has been given to the analysis of the
fluidization jet penetration depth and fluidization radii at the pile tip. These variables are shown to be controlled
by combined effects of jet velocity and the ratio of particle and jet diameter, being conveniently expressed by the
Froude number of particles. Once the prediction of fluidized zone geometry from system variables was completed,
the additional requirement was referred to the density of the fluidized sand bed prior and after fluidization. Despite
the initial density, the sand approaches the same low density after fluidization which is a state close to critical state
soil conditions. Variation in density impacts the prediction of pile bearing capacity: the shaft tensile capacity of
jacked piles is shown to reduce considerably when compared to the same pile installed in the ground by fluidization.

TORPEDO PILE INSTALLATION BY VERTICAL JET 
FLUIDIZATION IN GRANULAR SOILS 
 
Larissa de Brum Passini 
Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul, Porto Alegre, Brazil, larissapassini@hotmail.com 
 
Fernando Schnaid 
Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul, Porto Alegre, Brazil, fschnaid@gmail.com 
 
ABSTRACT: The torpedo pile is an anchoring offshore structure system widely used in Brazil in 
deep waters. The installation procedure consists in the release of the torpedo from a high position 
from the sea bottom to allow the device to reach its terminal velocity. Penetration depth is a 
function of kinetic energy, weight and geometry of the torpedo, seabed shear resistance and 
penetration angle. Since penetration in sand may not be sufficient to provide the necessary anchor 
bearing capacity, an alternative procedure is to combine the free-fall energy to soil fluidization. This 
alternative is evaluated in this paper by considering the use of circular, single and continuous 
vertical jets from the tip of model torpedo piles. Laboratory tests were performed in a reduced 
model using tubes to simulate torpedo without wings, following the law of similarity of Froude 
number. Pile penetration is shown to be a function of the pile weight, flow rate, jet velocity and 
relative density of sand bed. 
 
 
KEYWORDS: Torpedo Piles, Fluidization, Fine Sand. 
 
 
1 INTRODUCTION 
 
The oil industry has emerged as a major source 
of accelerating the development of Brazil, both 
economically and technologically, for example, 
with the oil exploration in waters and in deeper 
and deeper layers. The recent discovery by 
Petrobras of the existence of oil in the pre-salt 
region, in the basins of southern and 
southeastern Brazil, determined the offshore 
exploitation frontier to move fast to water 
depths and requiring development of new 
technologies related to the installation and 
fixing of offshore structures. 
 The installation costs increase as the water 
depth increases. The high number of floating 
production and drilling units may congest of the 
sea bottom due to the high number of risers and 
mooring lines employed. In order to minimize 
this problem, taut leg mooring systems are 
commonly employed by the offshore oil 
industry, e.g. Kunitaki (2006) and Costa (2008). 
The torpedo anchor (Figure 1) developed by 
Petrobras has proven to be an outstanding 

alternative for deep water, high load applied and 
low ground capacity in taut leg mooring 
systems, e.g. Medeiros (2002) and Henriques Jr. 
et al., (2010). This anchor requests simple 
installation equipment with low cost.  
 Torpedo piles are released from a designated 
height above the seafloor and penetrate to a 
target depth in the seabed by the kinetic energy 
obtained through free fall and through the own 
weight of the anchor, e.g. O’Loughlin, et al., 
(2004), Silva (2008), and Lavieri (2011). 
Brazilian offshore fields are majority composed 
by clayey seabed, where the torpedo pile 
reaches a satisfactory depth penetration, but 
some of them are sandy and the anchor cannot 
drill enough. Therefore, fluidization can be used 
to help the anchor installation using vertical jets 
from the tip of the torpedo. 
 Fluidization is the suspension of soil 
particles due to the action of an upward flow, 
which creates a force sufficient to support the 
actual weight of the particles drag (Figure 2), 
according to Leva (1959). The principles and 
mechanisms of fluidization sandy soils using 



suspended tubes have been studied and used in 
the navigation channel engineering, 
environmental engineering and the study of 
erosion caused by the impact of the water jet on 
the bed, e.g. Westrich & Kobus (1973), 
Rajaratnam & Beltaos (1977), Rajaratnam 
(1982), Weisman et al., (1982, 1988), Weisman 
& Lennon (1994), Aderibigbe & Rajaratnam 
(1996) and Niven (1998). 
 

 
Figure 1. Petrobras torpedo anchor, after Araujo et al. 
(2004). 

 

 
Figure. 2. Schematic representation of the fluidization 
using suspended tubes, after Niven (1998). 

 
 Fluidization is also used in onshore and 
nearshore foundation engineering, as well as in 
systems and operations offshore. Despite the 
fact that it is being extensively used in 
foundation engineering, relatively little 
information is available regarding the process 
fluidization, e.g. Shestopal (1959), Tsinker 
(1972, 1977, and 1988), Gabr, et. al. (2007), 
Zeilinger (2009) and Bhasi et. al. (2010), and 
empirical approaches are often used in design.  
 Recent studies on the mechanisms and 
parameters involved in the fluidization process 
have been presented by Mezzomo (2009), 

Stracke (2012), Alsaydalani & Clayton (2013) 
and Schnaid et. al. (2004). The present paper 
extends these early views by exploring the 
installation mechanisms of torpedo piles in 
granular soils. 
 
 
2 EXPERIMENTAL PROGRAM 
 
2.1 Materials and Methods 
 
The tests were performed using no plastic, clean 
and fine sand with uniform particle size (Table 
1 and Figure 3), from a natural deposit located 
at the city of Osorio in southern Brazil.
